prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The selected galaxies all have dust masses >3x10^5 Msun, and thus using a conservative gas-to-dust ratio of 50 (e.g. Smith et al., 2012) we expect each object to have at least 10^7 Msun of molecular gas. Some of the sample galaxies have shallow CO(1-0) single-dish fluxes from the SEST survey of Horellou et al (1995), and indeed their H$_2$ masses are all greater than 5x10^7 Msun.
With the sensitivity of ALMA we propose to map these objects with a 3 sigma surface density limit of ~10 Msun pc^-2. This will ensure we create a good map of each resolved source, and that our survey has consistent data quality. This is also the same sensitivity limit reached by surveys of Virgo cluster and field objects (e.g. Regan et al., 2001, Alatalo et al., 2013) ensuring we can compare directly. The CO linewidths found by Horellou range from 30-250 km/s. We thus base our sensitivity estimate on 10 km/s channels, to ensure we have at least 3 channels per line. As a guide we use a `standard' CO-to-H_2 X-factor (thought to be applicable in high-metallicity environments like Fornax; Dickman, Snell & Schloerb 1986) and an average line width of 200 km/s, and estimate that we need 4.0 mJy/beam in 10 km/s channels to fulfill our science goals.
Correlator setup: We aim here to detect the CO(1-0) line in these systems, and as argued above we require ~10 km/s channels. We thus propose to use the 1875 MHz basebands, with a raw resolution of 976 kHz ($\approx$3 \kms), which we will bin up to 10 km/s in post processing. Face on sources tend to be brighter than edge on galaxies, and this configuration gives us the flexibility to relax our binning for face on sources, or increase it for edge on ones to get higher sensitivity. We place one spectral window on 12CO, and another on the nearby CN lines (but these do not drive our time estimate). In the lower sideband we use the continuum setup of two overlapping 2GHz spectral windows with 31MHz (90 \kms) resolution to give us the ability to detect any continuum from these galaxies (and accurately remove it from our line observations).
Imaging requirements: We request the lowest resolution C32-1 array for this study in order to reasonably match the resolution of available ancillary data (Herschel ~7 arcsec, GALEX 5 arcsec), and ensure our data is comparable to the CO maps available for other clusters (e.g. 4-5 arcsec; Alatalo et al., 2012). This will also allow us to achieve the high surface brightness sensitivity in reasonably short integrations.
This science goal contains 13 sources which our Herschel imaging reveal have sufficiently compact CO reservoirs to allow a single pointing to cover all the gas. Experience shows that at the angular resolution we request the sources will be unresolved in each channel along the kinematic axis of the system (tracing the `spider diagram') and thus only the minor axis size where we expect molecular gas is important when considering the largest angular size of the source. At this resolution the maximum angular scale detectable is ~25 arcsec. These objects all have minor axes that are sufficiently small (<20") that we do not expect to resolve out flux here, and hence we do not require ACA observations.

The selected galaxies all have dust masses >3x10^5 Msun, and thus using a conservative gas-to-dust ratio of 50 (e.g. Smith et al., 2012) we expect each object to have at least 10^7 Msun of molecular gas. Some of the sample galaxies have shallow CO(1-0) single-dish fluxes from the SEST survey of Horellou et al (1995), and indeed their H$_2$ masses are all greater than 5x10^7 Msun.
With the sensitivity of ALMA we propose to map these objects with a 3 sigma surface density limit of ~10 Msun pc^-2. This will ensure we create a good map of each resolved source, and that our survey has consistent data quality. This is also the same sensitivity limit reached by surveys of Virgo cluster and field objects (e.g. Regan et al., 2001, Alatalo et al., 2013) ensuring we can compare directly. The CO linewidths found by Horellou range from 30-250 km/s. We thus base our sensitivity estimate on 10 km/s channels, to ensure we have at least 3 channels per line. As a guide we use a `standard' CO-to-H_2 X-factor (thought to be applicable in high-metallicity environments like Fornax; Dickman, Snell & Schloerb 1986) and an average line width of 200 km/s, and estimate that we need 4.0 mJy/beam in 10 km/s channels to fulfill our science goals.
Correlator setup: We aim here to detect the CO(1-0) line in these systems, and as argued above we require ~10 km/s channels. We thus propose to use the 1875 MHz basebands, with a raw resolution of 976 kHz ($\approx$3 \kms), which we will bin up to 10 km/s in post processing. Face on sources tend to be brighter than edge on galaxies, and this configuration gives us the flexibility to relax our binning for face on sources, or increase it for edge on ones to get higher sensitivity. We place one spectral window on 12CO, and another on the nearby CN lines (but these do not drive our time estimate). In the lower sideband we use the continuum setup of two overlapping 2GHz spectral windows with 31MHz (90 \kms) resolution to give us the ability to detect any continuum from these galaxies (and accurately remove it from our line observations).
Imaging requirements: We request the lowest resolution C32-1 array for this study in order to reasonably match the resolution of available ancillary data (Herschel ~7 arcsec, GALEX 5 arcsec), and ensure our data is comparable to the CO maps available for other clusters (e.g. 4-5 arcsec; Alatalo et al., 2012). This will also allow us to achieve the high surface brightness sensitivity in reasonably short integrations.
This science goal contains 5 sources which our Herschel imaging reveal have sufficiently elongated gas and dust reservoirs to need a small mosaic cover all the gas. Experience shows that at the angular resolution we request the sources will be unresolved in each channel along the kinematic axis of the system (tracing the `spider diagram') and thus only the minor axis size where we expect molecular gas is important when considering the largest angular size of the source. These sources are all edge on galaxies, and thus the largest angular scale is always smaller than 20", which means that we do not expect to resolve out flux, and hence we do not request ACA observations.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to map the CO(1-0) emission in all 19 FIR bright galaxies in Fornax cluster. This southern cluster is an ideal target for ALMA, as it has been little studied in the past. It is more dynamically relaxed, and has a much denser core than Virgo, but is less massive, inviting comparisons. Our team recently obtained Herschel observations of the cluster (revealing the cold dust component), optical integral field unit observations (revealing the ionised gas components) and have been allocated time to complete a deep HI survey (with ATCA). ALMA observations of the molecular gas in these objects will allow us to construct the first ever complete census of the cold ISM in the Fornax cluster. We will use this spatially resolved data to 1) disentangle environmental effects such as ram-pressure stripping, strangulation and harassment, and which most effects the molecular gas in the evolved Fornax cluster 2) study the origin and fate of the gas 3) probe star-formation and the HI-to-H2 conversion in cluster galaxies 4) determine galaxy scaling relations, and 5) provide the community with an excellent legacy dataset.
